{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3723140,"name":"Alex","username":"AlexClute","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alexclute/{size}/268859_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-25T19:25:11.955Z","cooked":"

I’ve been helping a team recently to get their swerve code working for an off-season competition coming up, and decided to use CTRE’s swerve code generator to make it easier to understand for the students on the team. Things went well and everything was working until we went to tune the PID controllers. Thats when two of our swerve pod’s rotational motors stopped responding to the code.

Symtoms:

  • LEDs on the motor blink orange when disabled and stay solid orange on enable, even as all other swerve pods move.
  • In TunerX, motor shows up and blinks the physical motor
  • When trying to control the motor in TunerX, turn motor doesn’t respond, but all others do

Attempted Troubleshooting:

  • I flipped the CAN ID of the turn and drive motor in the TunerConstants file.
    • This caused the turn motor to start spinning, but drive didn’t work
  • After that test, I tried resetting the ID numbers away from the original ID
    • Nothing changed, the same motor still didn’t respond
  • I then created a new code, with the only action being initializing the motor in the class method, then in teleopPeriodic, calling motor.set(.05);
    • Motor worked as it should, spinning slowly

If anyone has any ideas on what could cause this, I would love to try more things. Didn’t end up trying a different motor in its place due to wiring constraints, but we may try that when I go back.

Thanks!

Alex Clute

FTC 9933 and 17064 Programming Mentor

FRC 2337 Alumni

Can you share your code? Any logging you have could also help.

Will post code when I end up going back, but am unable to for now.

Do the two steer motors report a Fault_RemoteSensorDataInvalid fault? If so, the two steer motors are not seeing their corresponding CANcoders. In that circumstance, double check that all the CANcoders are blinking bright green, show up in Tuner X, and have the correct IDs and are on the same CAN bus as the rest of the drivetrain.

Will have to look at that, I know that the CANcoders are on the same CAN bus and that they were seen. Would this prevent TunerX from being able to control the motor? Also, where would I find the fault log?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-08-25T19:53:25.333Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":121,"readers_count":120,"score":44.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505662,"topic_slug":"ctre-swerve-generator-motors-not-working-properly","display_username":"Alex","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76880,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Just doing my best"},"post_url":"/t/ctre-swerve-generator-motors-not-working-properly/505662/5","custom_user_title":"Just doing my best","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3723212,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-25T21:10:24.812Z","cooked":"
AlexClute:

Would this prevent TunerX from being able to control the motor?

It would prevent all closed-loop control from running, regardless of the source of the control (Tuner X, robot code, etc.), but it would not prevent any open-loop control (such as DutyCycleOut in Tuner X or motor.set(0.05) in robot code).

AlexClute:

Also, where would I find the fault log?

Faults are status signals on the device (see getFault_RemoteSensorDataInvalid). They can also be seen inside of a Tuner X Self Test.
